DOC.HEAD: Group Sends First Shipment of Medical Supplies to Panama
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: A group led by the cousin of U.S.-backed Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sent its first shipment of medical supplies to Panama Tuesday and announced further plans to send medicine and food. The estimated $50,000 worth of supplies, including plasma and antibiotics, was accompanied by a physician to help distribute the items at Panama City's two main hospitals. ``We realize this is just a small amount of what's needed, but at this point anything is a help. These supplies are urgently needed,'' said Luis Endara Jr., whose cousin was sworn in as president last week after a U.S. invasion toppled the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The supplies, mostly donated to the Help Panama group from several South Florida hospitals, were packed in boxes and filled nearly every available space aboard the twin-engine Lear 25 jet. Other items sent included syringes and needles, intravenous solutions and orthopedic devices. Dr. Roberto Reyna said he would spend several hours in Panama to allocate the 2,500 pounds of supplies before returning late Tuesday to Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. Reyna said the group hopes the campaign for medical and food provisions will expand nationwide. ``The next flight, I hope we have a 747,'' he said. Help Panama also has opened accounts at two Miami banks to take donations, Luis Endara said. A cargo ship with six 40-foot containers of food is expected to leave Miami on Friday for the four-day voyage to Panama, he said. Earlier this week, the U.S. Air Force sent medical supplies aboard a C-5 cargo plane to Panama to aid injured civilians. The U.S. military has not released figures on civilian casualites or injuries. Luis Endara said he plans to continue relief and fund-raising efforts in the United States and does not foresee a direct role in his cousin's government. The situation at Panamanian hospitals was complicated by the Noriega regime using medical supply areas to hide arms, according to Roberto Dominguez, who was named the Panamanian consul in Miami on Tuesday. ``It's going to take a lot more shipments like these to return the hospitals to where they should be,'' Dominguez said.
